rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 

Recognising emotions in ourselves and our children is an important skill.

Talking about feelings helps our children learn to express and manage their emotions – even the difficult ones.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 

Recognising emotions in ourselves and our children is an important skill.

Talking about feelings helps our children learn to express and manage their emotions – even the difficult ones.

media_title.eng: How will talking about feelings with your children help you and your family? Tap play to find out

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get really angry, upset and you don’t know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. You start with noticing and accepting all the emotions we have. We are all human.

rows.media_title: How will talking about feelings with your children help you and your family? Tap play to find out
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get really angry, upset and you don’t know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. You start with noticing and accepting all the emotions we have. We are all human.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s take a look at how @data.characters.f3_mother.name and her daughter, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name, talk about feelings in a practical way:

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s take a look at how @data.characters.f3_mother.name and her daughter, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name, talk about feelings in a practical way:

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name, I have 5 minutes to spend one-on-one time with you. What would you like to do?

character_2_text.eng: Let’s play with the ball outside!

rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name, I have 5 minutes to spend one-on-one time with you. What would you like to do?
rows.character_2_text: Let’s play with the ball outside!

character_2_text.eng: I see that your hands are tight and you are speaking loudly. It looks like you are upset, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name. It’s not easy, let’s practise a little bit more. I know you can do it.

rows.character_2_text: I see that your hands are tight and you are speaking loudly. It looks like you are upset, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name. It’s not easy, let’s practise a little bit more. I know you can do it.

rows.character_1_text: Five throws in a row! You seem really proud to have made it to five!

character_1_text.eng: Five throws in a row! You seem really proud to have made it to five!
Well done! I am very happy to be able to spend this time with you, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name.

rows.character_1_text: Well done! I am very happy to be able to spend this time with you, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s talk about what happened when @data.characters.f3_mother.name and @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name decided to play ball outside.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s talk about what happened when @data.characters.f3_mother.name and @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name decided to play ball outside.

quiz_1_question.eng: Why does @data.characters.f3_mother.name name @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s feelings when she’s feeling angry and then proud?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Not quite. Naming emotions might not make someone feel better right away. The goal is to help her recognize her feelings so she can handle them better next time.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: To help @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name learn to recognise her own emotions

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That’s right. By naming @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s emotions, @data.characters.f3_mother.name models an important skill.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: To teach @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name how to solve problems on her own

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Not really. While solving problems is important, the main goal here is to help @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name recognise her emotions. Once she knows what she’s feeling, she’ll be better at solving problems next time.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: To distract @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name from what’s bothering her

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Not quite. The goal isn’t to take her mind off her feelings. By naming her emotions, @data.characters.f3_mother.name is helping @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name understand what she’s feeling, so she can deal with it better next time.

rows.quiz_1_question: Why does @data.characters.f3_mother.name name @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s feelings when she’s feeling angry and then proud?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Not quite. Naming emotions might not make someone feel better right away. The goal is to help her recognize her feelings so she can handle them better next time.
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: To help @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name learn to recognise her own emotions
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That’s right. By naming @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s emotions, @data.characters.f3_mother.name models an important skill.
rows.quiz_1_option_3_text: To teach @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name how to solve problems on her own
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Not really. While solving problems is important, the main goal here is to help @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name recognise her emotions. Once she knows what she’s feeling, she’ll be better at solving problems next time.
rows.quiz_1_option_4_text: To distract @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name from what’s bothering her
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Not quite. The goal isn’t to take her mind off her feelings. By naming her emotions, @data.characters.f3_mother.name is helping @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name understand what she’s feeling, so she can deal with it better next time.

rows.text_1_facilitator: We can learn a lot from @data.characters.f3_mother.name.

text_1_facilitator.eng: We can learn a lot from @data.characters.f3_mother.name.

text_2.eng:
Notice how she: 
- 🗣️ Names @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s positive *and* difficult emotions
- 💜 Accepts whatever emotions @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s is feeling
- 🌹 Stays calm despite @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s frustration
- 😌 Uses words to describe @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s emotions
- ⭐ Shares her own feelings

quiz_1_question.eng: What could have happened if @data.characters.f3_mother.name had criticised or ignored @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s frustration?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Correct. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to help our children learn how to deal with their feelings.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: The same problem would happen again next time

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That’s right. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn how to deal with their emotions.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name would not have learned how to catch a ball

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Exactly. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn new skills.

rows.text_2:
Notice how she: 
- 🗣️ Names @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s positive *and* difficult emotions
- 💜 Accepts whatever emotions @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s is feeling
- 🌹 Stays calm despite @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s frustration
- 😌 Uses words to describe @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s emotions
- ⭐ Shares her own feelings
rows.quiz_1_question: What could have happened if @data.characters.f3_mother.name had criticised or ignored @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name’s frustration?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Correct. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to help our children learn how to deal with their feelings.
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: The same problem would happen again next time
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That’s right. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn how to deal with their emotions.
rows.quiz_1_option_3_text: @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name would not have learned how to catch a ball
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Exactly. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn new skills.

rows.text_1_facilitator: With these three tips, you can help your child learn to manage their emotions well.

text_1_facilitator.eng: With these three tips, you can help your child learn to manage their emotions well.

section_1_text.eng: Recognise the *positive* and *difficult* emotions that you and your child feel.

section_1_extra_text.eng: To recognise feelings, pay attention to your thoughts and to your and your child’s words and actions.

section_2_text.eng: Be open to how you and your child feel. All feelings are okay.

section_2_extra_text.eng:
There are six basic emotions. Each send us an important message:
😊 Happy: Keep doing things that make you feel good. 

☹️ Sad: Something important in your life needs attention.

😠 Angry: Stand up for yourself and set limits.

🤢 Disgusted: Move away from something you don't like.

😯 Surprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.

😨 Afraid: Run away from danger.
 
As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

section_3_text.eng:
Use words to describe your and your child’s emotions, so they can learn to do the same. 
 
This may be hard at first, but it is an important step to help manage emotions!

section_3_extra_text.eng:
Describe how you see your child’s emotion in a calm way. For example:
 
*“I notice you’re stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry?”*
 
Share your own feelings with your child. For example: 
 
*“I know, I feel the same way when I can’t go out when I want to.”*
 
This shows your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

rows.section_1_text: Recognise the *positive* and *difficult* emotions that you and your child feel.
rows.section_1_extra_text: To recognise feelings, pay attention to your thoughts and to your and your child’s words and actions.
rows.section_2_text: Be open to how you and your child feel. All feelings are okay.

There are six basic emotions. Each send us an important message:
😊 Happy: Keep doing things that make you feel good. 

☹️ Sad: Something important in your life needs attention.

😠 Angry: Stand up for yourself and set limits.

🤢 Disgusted: Move away from something you don't like.

😯 Surprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.

😨 Afraid: Run away from danger.
 
As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

Use words to describe your and your child’s emotions, so they can learn to do the same. 
 
This may be hard at first, but it is an important step to help manage emotions!
rows.section_3_extra_text:
Describe how you see your child’s emotion in a calm way. For example:
 
*“I notice you’re stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry?”*
 
Share your own feelings with your child. For example: 
 
*“I know, I feel the same way when I can’t go out when I want to.”*
 
This shows your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s put the tips you have learnt into practice.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s put the tips you have learnt into practice.

quiz_1_question.eng: @data.characters.f1_mother.name and her son are running late. Her son is struggling to tie his shoes but refuses help. How can @data.characters.f1_mother.name respond?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: Tie his shoes for him and get out the door. We are late!

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: It is never fun to run late, but @data.characters.f1_mother.name will miss the opportunity to help her son learn to deal with his frustration if she doesn't help him first recognise what he’s feeling.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: Understand that her son is feeling frustrated and help him name his feelings

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That’s a great idea. She can also commit to practising shoe tying with him later, when he’s calmer, and praise him for naming his feelings and for making a good effort!

rows.quiz_1_question: @data.characters.f1_mother.name and her son are running late. Her son is struggling to tie his shoes but refuses help. How can @data.characters.f1_mother.name respond?
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: Tie his shoes for him and get out the door. We are late!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: It is never fun to run late, but @data.characters.f1_mother.name will miss the opportunity to help her son learn to deal with his frustration if she doesn't help him first recognise what he’s feeling.
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: Understand that her son is feeling frustrated and help him name his feelings
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That’s a great idea. She can also commit to practising shoe tying with him later, when he’s calmer, and praise him for naming his feelings and for making a good effort!

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Your home activity this week is to take a moment each day to talk about feelings – yours and your child’s. 
You can even try it out during one-on-one time today!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Your home activity this week is to take a moment each day to talk about feelings – yours and your child’s. 
You can even try it out during one-on-one time today!

media_title.eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_female_8.name taught her daughter skills by naming her emotions

media_transcript.eng:
My daughter used to get so frustrated and angry when she did not get her way. She would shout and scream, even when we went out, and I would also feel very angry and embarrassed. 

When I learned about emotions, I started to name and acknowledge her emotions. I helped her understand that it is okay to feel angry sometimes, but that she can show it in a different way. Now, she will tell me when she starts to feel angry, and we can find a solution together that works for everyone.

quiz_1_question.eng: Can you notice and talk about your and your child’s feelings today?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That’s great! It might be awkward to talk about feelings at first, but it will get better for everyone with practice.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Give it a try! It might be awkward to talk about feelings at first, but it will get better for everyone with practice.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. Learning to share emotions with our children can be challenging. You can start by recognising and naming one emotion you or your child felt today.
